clinical_study.brief_title: Passive Tactile Stimulation for Stroke Rehabilitation
clinical_study.official_title: Passive Tactile Stimulation for Stroke Rehabilitation

brief_summary.textblock: Stroke can lead to weakness and spasticity in the arm or hand. The purpose of this study is to optimize the design of gentle vibratory stimulation delivered to the hands of individuals with chronic stroke, and explore the effect on range of movement and spasticity.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Modified Ashworth at 16 weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Modified Ashworth at 16 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Modified Ashworth Scale for Spasticity (upper limb)

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Modified Ashworth at 8 weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Modified Ashworth at 8 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Modified Ashworth Scale for Spasticity (upper limb)

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Range of Motion at 16 weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Range of Motion at 16 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Workspace of voluntary movement of arm will be measured

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Range of Motion at 8 weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Range of Motion at 8 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Workspace of voluntary movement of arm will be measured

arm_group.description: Each tactile vibration pattern will consist of a specific vibration frequency, amplitude, and temporal sequence to be specified via pilot studies.

A light will blink instead of a vibration pattern being displayed.

intervention.description: PHASE 1 and PHASE 2 are pilot studies not included in the clinical trial. PHASE 3 (24 patients, 2 weeks each) Patients will be given a wearable device to take home. The patient will wear the device while feeling vibrations for 3 hours during the day while awake. At the beginning and end of the phase, each patient will be tested using one or more of the following metrics: Fugl-Meyer, strength, Ashworth, and range of motion. PHASE 4 (20 patients and 20 patients who routinely receive Botox injection) This study takes 4 or 8 months. 1) If the patient gets Botox injections in their hand and arm, their arm function will be measured for four months during this standard care. 2) Next, all patients will be given a wearable device to take home. The patient will wear the device while feeling vibrations for 3 hours during the day while awake for 8 weeks. During this time and two months after this intervention, arm movements and strength will be tested.
These patients will wear a glove with a blinking light instead of feeling vibrations.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 18 and older.
- diagnosis of stroke with upper extremity spasticity or other movement deficits that affect strength and range of movement.
- willing to participate in the vibrotactile stimulation sessions for consecutive days and willing to return for follow up visits as needed for the PHASE in progress.
- able to provide informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with severe contracture that precludes Modified Ashworth Score (MAS) testing.
